p: A relatively unbiased contribution to dissect the genetic control of plant metabolic diversity can come from genome-wide association studies (GWAS), which explore variation in breeding and natural populations and associate genetic variance to traits of interest, identifying specific QTLs. In cases where accurate metabolite evaluation methods were available, GWAS have been applied to plant metabolic studies (mGWAS) [ 116], and have proven to be more successful in identifying strong QTLs than GWAS applied to agronomic traits, possibly because of the large natural variation and high heritability of SMs accumulation [ 117]. Unlike GWAS for complex traits, mGWAS for accumulation of specialized metabolites tend to identify enzyme-coding genes rather than regulatory features, facilitating the prediction of candidate genes within genomic regions [ 117].
